- PCAR closed at **$124.90** on February 19, 2026, down **-0.216%** from the prior day's $125.17
- Stock has fallen **3 days in a row** and in **8 of the last 10 days**, declining **-3.01%** over that period
- Daily trading range on Feb 19: **$124.00–$125.33** (1.07% fluctuation)

### Technical Signals
- **Short-term Moving Average:** Sell signal (resistance ~$126.43)
- **Long-term Moving Average:** Buy signal (support ~$121.81); short-term average remains above long-term, giving an overall **general buy signal**

<Summary source="https://www.marketbeat.com/instant-alerts/paccar-analyst-day-parts-finance-fuel-stronger-cycle-profits-as-2026-outlook-holds-2026-02-11/">
## Summary: PACCAR Analyst Day – Key Highlights

**Source:** MarketBeat article covering PACCAR's 2026 Investor Conference

---

### Structural Profitability Improvements (CEO Preston Feight)
- Compared 2014 vs. 2025 (similar truck volumes): revenue grew from $19B to $28B+; income rose from $1.4B to $2.6B; return on revenue improved from 7.2% to 9.3%
- Parts and financial services grew from **43% to 71% of total profit**, reducing cyclicality
- Adjusted net income doubled from $1.3B (2020 trough) to $2.6B (2025); more than doubled from $2.4B (2019 peak) to $5B (2023)
- Five-year average net income per truck nearly doubled from ~$9,500 to ~$18,000

### Manufacturing & Tariff Strategy (SVP Laura Bloch)
- $800M deployed over five years to increase manufacturing flexibility; capacity increased **17%** over three years
- Adopted **"build local-for-local"** strategy in North America in response to tariffs:
  - Medium-duty trucks moved from Canada to Chillicothe (Kenworth) and Denton (Peterbilt)
  - Refuse trucks moved from Mexico to Denton
- Expects **"more than 50% relief"** on tariff exposure through offset programs
- Deployment of Industry 5.0 and Vision AI tools for efficiency

### Product Updates
- **Kenworth:** New T880S high-horsepower vocational model launched
- **Peterbilt:** Model 589 delivering (12,589+ units since launch); Model 567 EV described as industry's first electric vocational-specific truck
- **DAF:** XD and XF electric trucks won International Truck of the Year (third win in five years)

### Market Share Gains
- North America heavy-duty: 24% (2005) → **30.4%** (2025)
- South America: under 3% → **7.7%** (2025)
- Australia: 24% → **27.7%** (2025)
- 2024 record ROIC of **55.5%**

### Powertrain & Regulatory Strategy (CTO John Rich)
- Clean internal combustion engines remain core; hybrids to complement; BEV for appropriate use cases; hydrogen under investigation but **no capital committed**
- **No delay** to U.S. 35 mg NOx standard for 2027; EPA may relax warranty/useful life requirements (update expected by end of March)
- Two all-new proprietary engine platforms in final development for 2027 NOx compliance
- Europe: Euro 7 NOx in 2029, GHG step-change in 2030 — regulations described as stable

### Parts Growth Strategy (President Kevin Baney)
- Total addressable retail parts market: **$70B** ($45B North America, $25B Europe/other)
- Current North America share: **15%**; Europe/other: **13%**
- Target: gain 5 percentage points over five years = **$3.5B incremental dealer retail parts sales by end of 2030**
- Key metrics: 21 parts distribution centers, 99.9% shipping accuracy, 70% of shipments within 24 hours
- **Second-owner opportunity** highlighted: $33B of the $45B North American market; PACCAR has 21% share with first owners vs. 13% with second owners; second owners spend ~$12,000/truck/year vs. ~$8,000 for first owners
- Over **380,000** PACCAR engines operating in trucks past year five

### Financial Services
- Operates in **26 countries**; provides captive financing supporting truck market share and dealer inventory financing

---

*Note: The article appears to be cut off before completing the Financial Services section. The summary reflects all available content.*
</Summary>

- **EPS:** $1.06, **missing estimates** of $1.08 by $0.02
- **Revenue:** $6.252 billion, **missing estimates** of ~$6.384 billion by ~$131.4 million

- 2 total insider trades — **0 purchases, 2 sales**:

  - CFO Brice J. Poplawski sold 3,369 shares (~$340K)

<Summary source="https://www.tradingview.com/news/stockstory:da67aa4a7094b:0-paccar-nasdaq-pcar-reports-sales-below-analyst-estimates-in-q4-cy2025-earnings/">
## Summary: PACCAR (PCAR) Q4 CY2025 Earnings Report
**Source:** TradingView | **Date:** January 27, 2026

### Key Financial Results
- **Revenue:** $6.25 billion — a **20.9% year-on-year decline**, missing analyst estimates of $6.66 billion by **6.1%**
- **EPS (GAAP):** $1.06, essentially **in line** with analyst consensus of $1.05 (down from $1.66 in Q4 the prior year)
- **Operating Margin:** 7.8%, down **3.6 percentage points** year-on-year (vs. 11.4% in Q4 CY2024)
- **Free Cash Flow Margin:** 15.3%, up from 13.4% in the same quarter last year

### Broader Performance Context
- PACCAR's 5-year revenue CAGR stands at **8.3%**, but the last two years show an annualized revenue **decline of 10.9%**, attributed to a **cyclical downturn** in the Heavy Transportation Equipment industry
- Two-year annualized EPS decline of **28.2%**, worse than the revenue decline trend
- Operating margin has averaged **11.6%** over five years but has deteriorated recently

### Forward Outlook (Analyst Estimates)
- Revenue expected to **grow 3.3%** over the next 12 months (below sector average)
- Full-year EPS projected at **$4.51**, implying **17.7% growth**

### Immediate Market Reaction
- The stock **fell approximately 3%** to **$118.50** immediately following the earnings release

### Overall Assessment (per article)
The article characterizes the quarter as broadly disappointing — revenue missed, operating margin declined year-on-year — while noting free cash flow improvement as a modest bright spot.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.morningstar.com/news/business-wire/20260127918107/paccar-achieves-very-good-annual-revenues-and-net-income">
## Summary: PACCAR Q4 & Full Year 2025 Financial Results (Morningstar/BusinessWire, January 27, 2026)

### Key Financial Results

**Q4 2025:**
- Quarterly revenues: **$6.82 billion** (down from $7.91 billion in Q4 2024)
- Net income: **$556.9 million ($1.06/diluted share)** (down from $872.0 million / $1.66/share in Q4 2024)

**Full Year 2025:**
- Annual revenues: **$28.44 billion**
- Net income: **$2.38 billion ($4.51/diluted share)**, including a $264.5 million after-tax non-recurring charge related to European civil litigation
- Adjusted (non-GAAP) net income: **$2.64 billion ($5.01/diluted share)** — described as the **fourth best in the company's 120-year history**
- Cash dividends declared: **$2.72/share** (including a $1.40/share year-end dividend paid January 7, 2026)

### Segment Highlights

- **PACCAR Parts:** Record annual revenues of **$6.87 billion** (up 3% from 2024); annual pre-tax income of $1.67 billion
- **PACCAR Financial Services:** Record annual revenues of **$2.21 billion** (up from $2.10 billion in 2024); pre-tax profit of $485.4 million (up 11%)

### Market Outlook (2026 Estimates)
- U.S. & Canada Class 8 truck industry retail sales: estimated **230,000–270,000 units** (2025 actual: 233,000)
- European above 16-tonne trucks: estimated **280,000–320,000 units** (2025 actual: 298,000)
- South American above 16-tonne trucks: estimated **100,000–110,000 units** (2025 actual: 115,000)

### Notable Management Commentary
- CEO Preston Feight characterized results as "very good," noting record performance in Parts and Financial Services
- Senior VP Laura Bloch cited improving truck orders in December, attributing it to tariff policy and emissions regulation clarity, and projected **a stronger truck market in 2026**
- The company noted its North American factories are "optimally located" to minimize costs under Section 232 truck tariff regulations
- Executive Chairman Mark Pigott stated PACCAR's shareholder returns have **exceeded the S&P 500 for the last 20 years**

### Other Notable Items
- DAF XF and XD Electric trucks named **International Truck of the Year 2026**
- Kenworth and Peterbilt held **30% U.S. and Canada Class 8 retail sales market share** in 2025
- PFS issued **$3.12 billion in medium-term notes** during 2025; holds A+/A1 credit ratings

*Note: The article appears to be truncated at the end, cutting off the Capital and R&D Investments section.*
</Summary>

**GPA (PCAR3) Shares Drop Over 10% in Session, Accumulate 23% Losses in 2026 Amid Short-Selling Pressure**
The shares of GPA (PCAR3), owner of the Pão de Açúcar retail group, fell more than 10% on Thursday, February 19, 2026, and led losses in the Ibovespa index. At 15:25 (Brasília time), the stock was down 9.23%, trading at R$ 3.05. On a year-to-date basis, the shares have declined approximately 23%, with a drop of about 20% in February alone. The stock was among the highest in terms of loaned shares, with a 15.41% short interest rate, indicating investor bets on continued declines. Short selling occurs when investors borrow shares, sell them immediately, and aim to repurchase them later at a lower price to return the shares and profit from the difference—this reflects skepticism about the company’s performance. GPA is set to release its financial results on Tuesday, February 24, after market close, with expectations that sales growth will lag behind inflation. In a recent report, JPMorgan described GPA as a premium retailer with strong brand reputation undergoing restructuring focused on deleveraging, returning to fundamentals, expense cuts, and margin improvement. However, despite incorporating continuous profitability improvements into its 2026 projections, the bank still views cash generation and leverage as concerns, even with expected lower interest rates. Revenue trends remain challenging due to pressured consumer demand.

**Decoding PACCAR Inc (PCAR): A Strategic SWOT Insight**
PACCAR Inc (PCAR) released its annual report for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2025, highlighting a diversified business model with the trucks segment contributing 74% of sales, parts 24%, and financial services 8%. The company's market valuation was $49.01 billion as of mid-2025. Strengths include market leadership with 30% share in North America's Class 8 segment and 15% in Europe's heavy-duty market, strong brand equity from Kenworth, Peterbilt, and DAF, a robust dealer network of over 2,200 independent dealers, a resilient parts business with 21 global distribution centers, and a strategically significant financial services segment that holds 51% of total assets. Weaknesses include exposure to economic cycles, sensitivity to commodity price fluctuations (steel, copper, aluminum, petroleum), and high regulatory compliance costs due to stringent environmental and safety standards. Opportunities lie in advancements in zero-emission technologies—battery-electric, hydrogen combustion, and hybrid trucks—supported by partnerships in battery manufacturing, global expansion into emerging markets, and investments in connected truck technologies like the PACCAR Connect fleet management system. Threats include intense competition from rivals introducing new vehicles and technologies that could erode market share. The analysis, provided by GuruFocus, is based on the 10-K filing and historical data, and is not financial advice.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2026 05:08 AM
Source:[GuruFocus](https://www.gurufocus.com/news/8629996/decoding-paccar-inc-pcar-a-strategic-swot-insight)

**Ibovespa Ends Lower as Vale Slumps and Global Markets Rally | Exame**
The Ibovespa closed on Wednesday, February 18, 2026, with a slight decline of 0.24%, settling at 186,016 points, in a low-liquidity session marked by the expiration of options on the index. This performance contrasted with gains in major U.S. stock markets: the S&P 500 rose 0.50%, the Dow Jones gained 0.26%, and the Nasdaq advanced 0.78%, driven by resilient U.S. economic data despite the end of the interest rate cut cycle in late 2025. In Brazil, Vale (VALE3) shares dropped 3.57%, dragging down the Ibovespa due to a decline in international iron ore prices. Banking stocks showed mixed results: BBDC4 fell 0.29%, BBAS3 rose 1.53%, SANB11 gained 1.86%, BPAC11 advanced 1.23%, and ITUB4 increased 0.46%. Petrobras shares rose modestly—PETR3 up 1.11% and PETR4 up 0.81%—but underperformed global oil prices. Crude futures surged: Brent for April closed at $70.35 (+4.35%), and WTI for March at $65.19 (+4.59%), fueled by escalating geopolitical tensions between Russia and Ukraine and the potential for joint military action by Israel and the U.S. in Iran. On the upside, Raízen (RAIZ4) led gains with a 6.35% increase, driven by Shell’s proposal to convert 25% of its debt into shares and plans to split the company with Cosan and BTG funds. PetroRecôncavo (RECV3) rose 3.59%, while GPA (PCAR3) was the worst performer, falling 4.55%. Externally, the Federal Reserve’s minutes revealed divided views on future monetary policy, with some officials advocating rate cuts, others favoring stability or even hikes if inflation remains sticky. Domestically, the Focus report showed the 2026 IPCA inflation forecast declined for the sixth consecutive week, falling from 3.97% to 3.95%, while the Selic rate projection remained unchanged at 12.25% by year-end. Earlier, the Central Bank announced the liquidation of Banco Pleno, a move closely watched by the market for its sectoral implications.

Among related stocks, Pure Cycle (PCYO) rose 3.9% to USD 11.39, while Evi Industries (EVI) fell 0.57% to USD 20.33, Larimar Therapeutics (LRMR) dropped 1.87% to USD 3.03, Mission -Bakersfield Ca (MSBC) remained flat at USD 100, and Abeona Therapeutics (ABEO) gained 0.4% to USD 5.04, closing at $5.01. Abeona Therapeutics’ price has ranged between $3.93 and $7.54 over the past year, with a price-to-earnings ratio of 3.89 and a price-to-book ratio of 1.59, indicating modest valuation and low volatility.

**U.S. Stocks Close Higher as Tech Rally Drives Gains Amid Volatile Market Conditions**
On Tuesday, February 17, 2026, U.S. stocks closed higher despite a weak start, driven by a rebound in technology stocks and support from financials. The S&P 500 index initially dropped 1.5% during the session but recovered to close up 0.5% at 6,843.22. Gains from NVIDIA and Apple offset declines in Microsoft and Oracle. The previous week saw a sharp sell-off in software companies and brokers due to concerns that AI could disrupt business models, resulting in the largest weekly decline for the three major U.S. indices since mid-November. Tim Ghriskey, senior investment portfolio strategist at Ingalls & Snyder, noted that investors are navigating multiple trends, leading to high market volatility. He added that AI-related investments are likely to regain favor. The upcoming Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) price index report will be a key focus for assessing inflation and its impact on the Federal Reserve’s interest rate cut trajectory. Earlier, a lower-than-expected consumer inflation report slightly increased market expectations for rate cuts this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 32.26 points (0.07%) to close at 49,533.17. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 31.72 points (0.14%) to end at 22,578.39. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index dipped 1.81 points (0.02%) to close at 8,136.05.

**Plastic Caps & Closures Market: Consumer Preferences Shaping Innovation**
The global plastic caps and closures market was valued at USD 45.22 billion in 2023 and is projected to reach USD 62.45 billion by 2030, growing at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 4.8% from 2024 to 2030. Growth is driven by rising demand from key end-use industries, including food and beverages, pharmaceuticals, and personal care. Increasing consumer preference for convenient, safe, and hygienic packaging—particularly in the post-pandemic era—has accelerated adoption of advanced closures such as tamper-evident (TE) and dispensing closures. Sustainability is a major market trend, with manufacturers adopting environmentally friendly materials like polypropylene (PP) and high-density polyethylene (HDPE), and launching closures made from post-consumer recycled (PCR) materials. Companies such as Berry Global and Aptar have introduced PCR-based closures, aligning with circular economy goals. The expanding beverage industry, especially in the Asia-Pacific region, further fuels demand. In pharmaceutical and personal care sectors, demand for child-resistant, precise-dispensing, and secure packaging solutions is creating opportunities for specialized closures. The market is highly competitive, with multinational corporations, regional players, and public companies competing on innovation, sustainability, and compliance with evolving regulations. Market leaders are expected to gain advantage by investing in recyclable materials, PCR content, and advanced tamper-evident technologies.

**GPA (PCAR3) Reports Turnaround in 3rd Quarter, But Leverage and Volatility Persist**
GPA (PCAR3), the parent company of Pão de Açúcar, reported a net profit of R$ 137 million for the third quarter of 2025, reversing a net loss of R$ 310 million in the same period of 2024. Despite modest results and ongoing challenges, PCAR3 shares rose 2.64% to R$ 3.89 (peaking at R$ 4.14) on November 5, 2025, driven by investor optimism over the company’s efficiency plans. The company achieved a positive free cash flow (FCF) supported by improved working capital dynamics, though weighed down by heavy financial results. GPA announced a cost-cutting plan for 2026, including reducing capital expenditures to between R$ 300 million and R$ 350 million (down from R$ 693 million in the 12 months ended September 30, 2025) and cutting operating expenses by at least R$ 415 million compared to 2025 estimates. The same-store sales (SSS) growth was 4.1%, slightly above expectations but below the 5.0% recorded in the third quarter of 2024. The Proximidade segment led with a 17.4% revenue increase (R$ 651 million), while the Aliados segment saw a 41.2% revenue drop due to strategic divestment to protect margins. Gross margin remained stable at 27.6%, aided by efficient supplier negotiations and pricing discipline. Adjusted EBITDA reached R$ 412 million (9.0% margin), surpassing market expectations, but EBIT was only R$ 47 million (1.0% margin) due to R$ 76 million in unexpected operational expenses, primarily from store closures and restructuring. The net profit was boosted by a one-time R$ 415 million tax credit, which elevated the profit from continuing operations to R$ 142 million. Analysts from Genial Investimentos and XP Investimentos noted that while operational improvements are evident, the recurring earnings power remains weak, with the profit inflated by non-recurring tax benefits. Both firms maintained a 'hold' (neutral) recommendation, with Genial setting a target price of R$ 3.50. The macroeconomic environment remains challenging, and high leverage (at 15% base interest rates) continues to pressure financial performance.

**PCAR Upgraded by Wolfe Research to 'Peer Perform' Rating | PCAR Stock News**
On October 22, 2025, Wolfe Research upgraded PACCAR Inc. (PCAR, Financial) from 'Underperform' to 'Peer Perform' without changing its price target. The upgrade reflects a more optimistic outlook on the company's stock market performance. This follows a series of recent analyst actions: On October 14, 2025, JP Morgan raised its price target from $97.00 to $103.00 (+6.19%); on October 8, 2025, Truist Securities lowered its price target from $98.00 to $97.00 (-1.02%); and on July 23, 2025, UBS upgraded from 'Sell' to 'Neutral' and raised its price target from $81.00 to $100.00 (+23.46%). PACCAR, a leading manufacturer of medium- and heavy-duty trucks under the Kenworth, Peterbilt, and DAF brands, operates primarily in the Americas, Australia, Europe, and South America. The company’s sales are distributed across the trucks segment (74%), parts (20%), and financing (6%), with a network of 2,200 independent dealers. PACCAR holds approximately 30% of the Class 8 market share in North America and 15% in Europe. Wall Street analysts' average one-year price target is $106.44, implying a 5.09% upside from the current price of $101.29. The consensus brokerage recommendation is 2.6 (indicating 'Hold'), based on 21 firms. GuruFocus estimates the one-year GF Value at $79.57, suggesting a 21.44% downside from the current price of $101.2855. The alert was generated using automated technology and reviewed by the GuruFocus editorial team.

**Wolfe Research Upgrades PACCAR (PCAR) to Peerperform**
Wolfe Research upgraded PACCAR (NASDAQ: PCAR) from 'Underperform' to 'Peerperform' based on revised earnings estimates and valuation analysis. The analyst, Scott Group, noted that PCAR is trading at 20x its trough 2025 EPS estimate, 20x its slightly recovering 2026 EPS estimate, and 15x its more normalized $6.80 EPS estimate, which compares to the stock's 5- and 10-year average forward P/E multiples of roughly 13x and 14x. The analyst expects PACCAR's gross margins to bottom in 4Q 2025 and believes the stock's performance is closely correlated with margin trends. While downside risk appears limited due to the margin trough, the analyst sees little upside as the 2026 EPS estimate remains below consensus. The upgrade reflects improved positioning relative to other truck OEMs amid Section 232 tariffs and rebates. PACCAR shares closed at $99.85 on October 21, 2025.
